column1: psliterary 160693679745 "2017-05-15 13:00:40 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160693679745/win-a-copy-of-the-antique-house-murders-by-leslie "Book two in Leslie Nagel‚Äôs Oakwood Mystery Series is releasing May 30th!! To celebrate Leslie‚Äôs giving away TEN copies! In this irresistible cozy mystery from the author of The Book Club Murders
column2: amateur sleuth Charley Carpenter fights to avenge a crime that hits far too close to home.  Mulbridge House stood
column3: silent and decaying
column4: deep in the woods at the  heart of Oakwood
column5: Ohio
column6: long before the passing of Augusta Mulbridge.  Yet suddenly everyone in town seems to have a stake in its fate: the  greedy heirs
column7: eager to tear it down for a tidy profit; the local  preservationists
column8: determined to maintain it as an historic site; the  angry neighbors
column9: staunchly opposed to the construction of a modern  subdivision. Even Charley Carpenter is forced to admit that her beloved  shop
column10: Old Hat Vintage Fashions
column11: could use an infusion of the estate‚Äôs  treasures. The clock is ticking. The wrecking ball is ready to  swing. All that stands between Mulbridge House and oblivion is one final  vote. That
column12: and murder ‚Ä¶ The trouble begins when Charley  walks into auctioneer Calvin Prescott‚Äôs office to find her cherished  family friend crumpled on the floor. Detective Marcus Trenault quickly  connects his death to a string of increasingly violent burglaries  plaguing Oakwood. But when Charley uncovers a link to a massive land  swindle worth millions
column13: not to mention a drug ring operating out of the  manor‚Äôs abandoned outbuildings
column14: that theory crumbles faster than  Mulbridge House. Now Charley‚Äôs racing to catch a killer before everything falls apart. " True text

psliterary 161020673519 "2017-05-24 13:30:22 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/161020673519/deals-when-the-beat-drops-by-anna-hecker-acquired "Anna Hecker queried me on my birthday last year
column2: with one wonderful gift.Her next novel.It was wild to me
column3: to discover that there weren‚Äôt any YA novels about  EDM‚Ä¶ Electronic Dance Music. Considering the current popularity of The  Chainsmokers
column4: the easy listening joy that is Owl City
column5: and my absolute  favorites
column6: Daft Punk
column7: how hasn‚Äôt this been explored?Well. Enter Anna with When the Beat Drops.In Anna‚Äôs latest novel
column8: she introduces readers to Mira Alden
column9: a teen girl who wants nothing more than to ace  her audition to the prestigious Fulton Jazz Conservatory. See
column10: she‚Äôs  essentially a teen jazz prodigy
column11: writing beautiful music with her best  friends as a somewhat band-geek outcast. And then she falls into the EDM  scene when her sister comes home‚Ä¶ and discovers a surprise gift for  DJing. Read the full post at EricSmithRocks.com" True link

column1: psliterary 160984062324 "2017-05-23 13:30:13 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160984062324/what-does-literary-agent-kurestin-armada-look-for " Tell us a bit about yourself. I decided to go into publishing for the usual reasons: books were  incredibly important to me growing up
column2: and a huge comfort at many times  in my life. It always felt a bit magical to find the right book at the  right time
column3: and when I realized that real people were involved in making  that magic happen
column4: the decision to go into publishing seemed natural. I  first tried my hand at publicity because I‚Äôve always preferred to work  with people and enjoy the selling aspect of the business
column5: but it was  very much ‚Äúend of the process‚Äù which I quickly realized was not a good  fit for me.Agenting
column6: which is the complete opposite end of the process
column7: seemed  like a natural alternative. And it turns out I love working with  projects I choose and believe in
column8: and I really enjoy using my  negotiating skills as an advocate for authors. I was lucky enough to  assist at an agency that works with some of the top names in SF/F  fiction
column9: which was just fantastic training with some really amazing  talent. Then I was ready to build my own list and well
column10: here I am! What mistakes are you seeing most often in SF/F queries
column11: and how can writers avoid them? I really think that SF/F queries are the most difficult ones to  write. The key (in my humble opinion) to any great query is of course  focusing on the character. It all falls apart without a concrete main  character to pin my emotions on. One mistake I often see is a query  that‚Äôs all about the elaborate magic system or the themes
column12: but nothing  about why the conflict is personal for that main character/why I want to  read an entire book about them.But equally important in an SF/F query is showing what makes the world: 1. Interesting
column13: and 2. Unique.The biggest problems I see in this area all come from a lack of  specificity. Vague phrases like ‚Äútrouble looms‚Äù or ‚Äúenemies surround  them‚Äù or ‚Äúa dark past‚Äù or even ‚Äúmagical powers‚Äù can apply to almost any  book
column14: which means your MS will sound boring [or] unoriginal and I won‚Äôt  feel the need to read it. The good
column15: interesting bits are always in the  specifics.If you‚Äôre in doubt
column16: try a three draft method. First
column17: vaguely sketch  out the events you need to include in the query
column18: keeping a decent  balance of character and world
column19: ending at the initial conflict that  pushes the MC into the meat of the book. Then
column20: go back and add as many  specific details as you can to replace any vague wording. (Why is there a  war? What are the powers? What trouble do they fear? Why do they care  about these people? Etc.) Lastly
column21: go back and prune because you‚Äôve  probably just written a monster of a query! Your best critiques are  going to come from people who have NOT read your manuscript (but who do  read in your genre).Read the full interview at Queership.com" True link

column1: psliterary 160872779158 "2017-05-20 13:45:39 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160872779158/the-20-10-method-is-the-best-way-to-clean-your "If you‚Äôre feeling  overwhelmed by your messy home
column2: and nothing you do seems to be making a  difference
column3: it just might be time to re-think how you look at cleaning.  Most people
column4: when faced with a messy disaster of a home
column5: usually do one  of two things:1. Wait until it gets to the point of being completely unbearable and then clean everything in a whirlwind marathon and then consider it done; or2. Decide it‚Äôs all too overwhelming and just give up entirely
column6: only cleaning things that are needed for immediate use and ignoring everything else because where do you even begin when everything is so terrible?Unfortunately
column7: neither one of those approaches is particularly effective or  sustainable. With marathon cleaning
column8: your home ends up completely clean  for a very short period of time
column9: and then the mess accumulates until you  reach your breaking point again. With avoidance
column10: you never make any  progress
column11: and you continue to be frustrated and overwhelmed by your home  all the time. But there is a better way. Rather than knocking yourself  out doing it all at once or pretending the mess isn‚Äôt there at all
column12: investing just a little bit of time every day (or
column14: most  days) will get you to a clean home that you can actually enjoy much  faster than you‚Äôd think.‚ÄúA 20/10 is 20 minutes of cleaning followed by a 10-minute break‚ÄùRead the full article at HouseBeautiful.com" True link

column1: psliterary 160655653748 "2017-05-14 13:00:46 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160655653748/steve-patterson-happy-mothers-day-2017 "Dear Moms
column2: On behalf of everyone who has or has had one or more of you
column3: thanks.Thanks for loving your children unconditionally despite behavior that  any other reasonable human would consider ‚Äúconditions to stop loving  someone‚Äù.Thanks for being personal chefs
column4: chauffeurs
column5: psychologists
column6: tutors
column7: coaches and relentless bodyguards despite not being paid for any of  these duties.Thanks for being our biggest fans when we do something remotely good  and our fiercest defenders when we do something completely bad.Thanks for putting up with dads who often are more like additional  offspring than equally contributing partners in a household (sorry about  that to my wife Nancy)Read Steve‚Äôs full letter at StevePatterson.ca & check out his book The Book of Letters I Didn‚Äôt Know Where to Send" True link

column1: psliterary 160584674313 "2017-05-12 13:30:22 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160584674313/fizzy-fangirling-an-interview-with-eric-smith "Today I am thrilled to bring you a chat with one of my absolute most  favorite folk in all of publishing
column2: literary agent/author/White Castle  enthusiast Eric Smith!1. First off
column3: how long have you been an agent? What made you want to dive into this wacky business in the first place?I‚Äôve been at it for two years as of‚Ä¶ wow
column4: as of just a week ago or so.I‚Äôd  spent a solid few years working at a publishing house in Philadelphia  (hi Quirk Books!)
column5: and while I adored every single minute of it
column6: I  wanted to really work on my own projects. When the opportunity to agent  surfaced
column7: with an agency that was on board for me to take on any wild  idea and just let me run with it
column8: I jumped at the chance.It‚Äôs definitely a wacky business
column9: but so extremely fulfilling. I love the book community.2. What genres do you represent? How important is the genre
column10: or will you take on something different just because it gives you the  feelings?I‚Äôm a little all over the place? Young Adult  across all genres‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs where my heart is
column11: absolutely. I‚Äôve sold more  YA than anything else. But I also really love quirky and hard hitting  non-fiction
column13: and cookbooks.Genre  is pretty important. Some stuff I just don‚Äôt quite get
column14: because I don‚Äôt  read enough of it. For example
column15: I don‚Äôt work on Middle Grade books
column16: because I simply haven‚Äôt read enough of it to feel confident that I‚Äôd  know what‚Äôs good. Same with say
column17: commercial horror novels.Read the full interview in all its gif glory at FizzyFangirling.com " True link

column1: psliterary 160333523708 "2017-05-05 13:00:23 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160333523708/deals-making-friends-with-giants-by-bassey-ikpi "Sometimes
column2: books start in the quirkiest of places.Like in a Facebook conversation with a friend from back home.Steve Clark
column3: a storyteller from back in Philadelphia who I‚Äôve seen  numerous time at various First Person Arts events
column4: sent me a message one  fateful day. He‚Äôs one incredibly gifted guy
column5: and my goodness
column6: I look  forward to seeing his book in stores one day. And when he brought up his  friend
column7: I was happy to take a look at the project
column8: and recommend other  agents for it
column9: in the event it wasn‚Äôt for me.Turns out
column10: it was definitely for me.Some of you might recognize Bassey Ikpi. And you should. Here‚Äôs her Twitter. Her Wikipedia.  You probably saw her on Def Poetry Jam
column11: or read one of her many essays  or articles around the Internet. I highly suggest checking out her gorgeous
column12: recent essays on Catapult. She‚Äôs a rockstar
column13: and I‚Äôm so happy Steve connected us.Continue reading at EricSmithRocks.com" True link

column1: psliterary 160083699176 "2017-04-28 13:30:34 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/160083699176/writing-the-hook-summing-your-book-up-quick-and "As an agent with a large social circle of writerly friends
column2: I often  find myself in that awkward position of helping pals polish up their  query letters. I don‚Äôt mind. Chances are
column3: if you work in publishing
column4: you‚Äôve been here. It‚Äôs the sort of thing I‚Äôve been doing since college
column5: when I was the English major stuck reviewing essays for friends.I‚Äôve come to accept this as simply the next stage in my English major evolution.The one issue I‚Äôve seen pop up time and time again
column6: whether it‚Äôs when  I‚Äôm helping friends with their query letters or critiquing queries at  conferences or mentoring my MFA students during my day job‚Ä¶ is the issue  of writing ‚Äúthe hook.‚ÄùThat is
column7: being able to sum up your book quickly and succinctly in a  sentence. Or maybe two. But preferably a sentence
column8: ideally with a  comparative title or two.‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs impossible!‚Äù You scream from your stone tower
column9: where  you‚Äôve been working on that epic novel that words simply cannot  describe. ‚ÄúNothing compares to my book. Nothing!‚Äù Lightning crashes.First of all
column10: stop screaming at me
column11: and secondly
column12: what is the rent  like on that cool tower you live in? Can I get in on that? Who is your  landlord?Listen. It is possible. And it needs to be possible. Otherwise you  may have written something that isn‚Äôt quite sellable. Or at least
column13: you  haven‚Äôt figured out how to talk about it in a way that‚Äôll make it  sellable.Continue reading at PublishingCrawl.com" True link

column1: psliterary 159903876900 "2017-04-23 16:30:20 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/159903876900/the-30-minute-home-cleaning-hack-everyone-should "If you‚Äôve ever experienced the life-changing magic of Marie Kondo or tried to feng shui your space
column2: you know that most home organization methods require planning‚Äîand a lot of effort to fully execute.No sweat if you‚Äôve got the stamina for a marathon pick-up
column3: but for the rest of us
column4: there‚Äôs Unf*ck Your Habitat: You‚Äôre Better Than Your Mess
column5: a  refreshingly realistic guide to spring (or anytime) cleaning that‚Äôs  simple
column6: flexible
column7: and adaptable to pretty much any lifestyle.‚ÄúI really strive to provide a practical framework for people to  follow
column8: ‚Äù says author Rachel Hoffman
column9: a self-professed ‚Äúreformed messy  person‚Äù whose candid
column10: unfussy approach to tidying up will actually make  you want to grab a broom.Visit WellAndGood.com to continue reading." True link

column1: psliterary 159824840160 "2017-04-21 13:00:39 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/159824840160/your-first-chapter-is-a-promise-to-your-reader "When it comes to pitch contests on the ol‚Äô social media
column2: and pitching  / getting requests from agents in general
column3: a lot of time you‚Äôre going  to be asked for the first few pages of your manuscript. Maybe a couple  of chapters. Hell
column4: some agents are going to want you to paste those  first pages in an email.Chances are
column5: if you‚Äôre a querying writer
column6: you‚Äôve already polished  these opening pages to perfection
column7: pouring over them again and again.Which is great
column8: but before I dig into talking about opening pages‚Ä¶  make sure the rest of your manuscript is as polished as those early  chapters.Done? Okay. Let‚Äôs continue.Now
column9: everything I‚Äôm about to prattle on about here is subjective.  Remember that
column10: writers. When it comes to pitching agents and editors
column11: sometimes it isn‚Äôt about how good your book is. Sometimes it‚Äôs about  taste. What that particular agent or editor enjoys reading. So make sure  you‚Äôre taking your time when doing your research
column12: and don‚Äôt take it  personally when something just doesn‚Äôt gel.In my opinion though
column13: a great set of first pages
column15: is one thing and one thing only.A first chapter is a promise between a book and the reader.Are you getting ready to read a fantasy novel and explore a lush
column16: imagined world? Is this a contemporary YA
column17: packed full of swoons? Are we  going to be scared? Thrilled? Challenged? Those first pages tell your  reader what they are in for
column18: and promises them that they can look  forward to more in the chapters ahead.Don‚Äôt break your promise.And no
column19: an unreliable narrator isn‚Äôt an example of breaking a  promise
column20: friends. You can usually tell when a narrator is messing with  you early on. And even if you can‚Äôt
column21: you‚Äôre promising more than just a  tricky storyteller. There‚Äôs the world. The people around your character.  The tone. The voice. The stakes.You should be able to establish that in the first chapter. And then
column22: you should be able to keep your promise.Let‚Äôs have a look at a few fantastic examples of diverse YA reads with kick ass opening pages.Read the full post at DailyDahlia.wordpress.com" True link

column1: psliterary 159569367437 "2017-04-14 16:30:23 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/159569367437/pecan-raspberry-pie-bars "Bake some of Allison Day‚Äôs Rasberry Pecan Pie Squares in honor of #NationalPecanDay! " True link
psliterary 159418361568 "2017-04-10 16:30:31 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/159418361568/interview-with-karen-katchur-author-of-the "What can you tell us about your new release
column2: The Sisters of Blue Mountain?In The Sisters of Blue Mountain
column3: I explore the relationship between  two sisters who were once as close as they could be
column4: and how a tragic  event
column5: one bad decision
column6: tears them apart. I wanted to find out whether  or not the sisters could find their way back to each other when they‚Äôre  tossed into the middle of a murder investigation.Who or what inspired you to become an author?Several years ago I was watching Oprah‚Äôs book club discuss the novel
column7: While I Was Gone
column8: by Sue Miller. The audience was divided about the actions of the main  character to the point where an argument broke out. As the discussion  continued
column9: it became more and more heated
column10: and I remember thinking
column11: I  want to do that. I want to write a story so real where readers feel so  passionately about a character(s) that they‚Äôre willing to argue about  it.It wasn‚Äôt until a couple of years later that I sat down to write my  first novel
column12: but I never forgot that Oprah show or the author.Read the full interview at NewInBooks.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158968610904 "2017-03-29 16:30:38 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158968610904/unfck-your-habitats-rachel-hoffman-is-not-as "I chatted with Rachel about her recent book while pacing around my house
column2: weaving around the fake Christmas tree that‚Äôs still up. In March.Question: I really loved Unf*ck Your Habitat: You‚Äôre Better Than Your Mess. My sister and I have followed the blog for a long time ‚Ä¶ What was your journey to starting it in the first place?Rachel Well
column3: I‚Äôm definitely what I generally refer  to as a reformed messy person. I feel like a lot of these books and  systems and everything are done by people who are very naturally neat  and very naturally tidy and clean. So it started out as me yelling at  people to get up and do what they have to do
column4: and it sort of morphed  from there
column5: turned into something a little bit different. It‚Äôs a lot  less mean than it used to be.Question: One thing that my sister and I were talking about  the other night ‚Äî we‚Äôre both very messy people
column6: and not reformed
column7: unfortunately
column8: we‚Äôre in the process of reforming ‚Ä¶ Rachel And reforming is a long journey
column9: trust me.Question: Right. But we talked about a couple of other approaches
column10: like the Fly Lady
column11: for example
column12: feel very traditional ‚Äî even the name kind of implies that  it‚Äôs a lady‚Äôs job to be doing this. And so another thing I really liked  about your book was that you have these sections about some of the  social constructs around cleaning in general.  Rachel: The very first thing I like to do is take  that assumption of
column15: and throw that out the  window
column16: because everybody who lives in a space should be responsible for  that space. And I think it does everybody a disservice if we‚Äôre saying okay
column18: so you don‚Äôt have to worry about this. It‚Äôs bullshit. And  then as far as the other kinds of people who have felt left behind by  these systems before ‚Äî you know
column19: people who do have disabilities or  invisible illnesses or mental illness ‚Äî those things are a very real  part of somebody‚Äôs life and they affect how they‚Äôre able to interact  with cleaning
column20: and how they‚Äôre able to interact with their home. Read the full interview at Ravishly.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158931924656 "2017-03-28 16:30:19 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158931924656/how-to-spring-clean-your-digital-habitat "Intent  on making 2017 your Best Year Ever? We can help with that
column2: thanks to  our 2017 Coach of the Month series. Here
column3: Rachel Hoffman‚Äîwho authored the just-released book Unfuck Your Habitat: You‚Äôre Better Than Your Mess‚Äîshares her no nonsense
column4: uncomplicated tips for decluttering your life‚Ä¶the sane way.With  the amount of time that so many of us spend online
column5: on our phones
column6: or  otherwise interacting with technology
column7: it‚Äôs important to remember that  our digital habitat is often in need of cleaning up just as much as our  physical one. Sure
column8: you‚Äôre unlikely to trip over digital clutter like  you would a pile of clothes
column9: but organization and upkeep are still  critical to keeping our digital lives clean
column10: streamlined
column11: and easy to  engage with.Spring clean your digital habitat with these easy-to-incorporate habits.SmartphoneFirst  and foremost
column13: what kind of state is your  home screen in? Are your apps sorted into logical folders or groups? Do  you have your most frequently used apps in places that are easy to get  to? How many of those apps have you not used in
column15: the past six  months? Your first objective should be to streamline and organize your  home screen so it‚Äôs intuitive and not too cluttered. Delete apps if you  don‚Äôt use them. Then give your contacts
column17: and text messages  the same treatment. Delete things you no longer need or use (or  anticipate needing for reference). To help keep things neat and  easy-to-use
column18: make sure that as you download new apps or add new contacts  that you‚Äôre taking an extra moment to place them where it makes sense  or to make sure you have a complete contact record right from the  beginning.Continue reading at Elle.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158664422030 "2017-03-21 13:00:33 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158664422030/the-20-10-method-is-the-smartest-way-to-clean "Intent  on making 2017 your Best Year Ever? We can help with that
column2: thanks to  our 2017 Coach of the Month series. Here
column3: Rachel Hoffman‚Äîwho authored the just-released book Unfuck Your Habitat: You‚Äôre Better Than Your Mess‚Äîshares her no nonsense
column4: uncomplicated tips for decluttering your life‚Ä¶the sane way.If  you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed by your messy home
column5: and nothing you do seems  to be making a difference
column6: it just might be time to re-think how you  look at cleaning. Most people
column7: when faced with a messy disaster of a  home
column8: usually do one of two things:1.  Wait until it gets to the point of being completely unbearable and then  clean everything in a whirlwind marathon and then consider it done; or2.  Decide it‚Äôs all too overwhelming and just give up entirely
column9: only  cleaning things that are needed for immediate use and ignoring  everything else because where do you even begin when everything is so  terrible?Unfortunately
column10: neither one of those approaches is particularly effective or  sustainable. With marathon cleaning
column11: your home ends up completely clean  for a very short period of time
column12: and then the mess accumulates until you  reach your breaking point again. With avoidance
column14: and you continue to be frustrated and overwhelmed by your home  all the time. But there is a better way. Rather than knocking yourself  out doing it all at once or pretending the mess isn‚Äôt there at all
column15: investing just a little bit of time every day (or
column17: most  days) will get you to a clean home that you can actually enjoy much  faster than you‚Äôd think.Continue reading at Elle.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158547059617 "2017-03-18 13:30:31 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158547059617/introducing-eric-smith "Eric Smith is now a contributing writer for Publishing Crawl!¬†Hi Eric! You‚Äôve worn so many hats in the publishing  industry‚Äîauthor
column2: agent
column3: and marketing‚Äîcan you tell us a bit about how to  you got started? Your journey
column4: as it were. So I had a pretty unconventional entrance into the world of  publishing
column5: but I feel like my way in is starting to happen a lot more  these days. Which is great. Please
column6: publishing. Please. Find talent in  different ways other than through resumes on your corporate websites.Anyhow. Back in Philadelphia I launched a popular local blog that ran  events
column7: reviewed things
column8: did interviews
column9: and the like. And it caught  the notice of a local publisher
column10: Quirk Books. I‚Äôd done some giveaways  for their titles at our events and on the site
column11: and they were looking  for a social media/blogging person for the publishing house. They wanted  to see if I could do what I did for my blog
column12: for them. I‚Äôd also been  working as a blog editor full-time for another company
column13: so the interests  certainly melded.Fast forward five years
column14: and I‚Äôd had an awesome experience working on titles like Miss Peregrine‚Äôs Home for Peculiar Children
column17: and so many more. I produced book trailers
column20: all kinds of fun stuff. And I loved it all.But
column21: I did want to work on some of my own passion projects
column22: so after  those glorious five years with some really brilliant people
column23: I went to  work with P.S. Literary. Quirk was putting out a title by one of the  authors represented there
column24: and I really loved a lot of the work my  now-colleagues had done (and continue to do). And now
column29: that‚Äôs another unconventional route. My colleague and  publisher at Quirk
column31: came to me with the idea for The Geek‚Äôs Guide to Dating. Like
column32: literally came downstairs to talk about it. I was thrilled
column33: and I wrote it while working on my YA projects. Inked (and soon Branded) came a bit later
column34: but my author career definitely took off thanks to the team at Quirk.Continue reading the interview at PublishingCrawl.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158509978915 "2017-03-17 13:00:48 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158509978915/3rd-annual-science-fiction-fantasy-online "Writer‚Äôs Digest University is pleased to present a one-of-a-kind  online event for science fiction and fantasy writers! ¬†On April 1st and  2nd
column2: our 3rd Annual Science Fiction & Fantasy Online  Writing Conference will provide expert insights from SIX award-winning  and bestselling authors on the finer points of how to write within the  science fiction and fantasy genres. ¬†Spend the weekend learning  techniques for honing your craft from six different published authors*
column3: then (if you choose) pitch your novel via query letter to a literary  agent specifically looking for material in these genres. The agent will  provide you with a personalized critique of your query ‚Äì and maybe ask  to see more. 	Experience the education
column4: camaraderie
column5: and opportunities provided by a  live writing conference without ever having to leave your home!  All participants will benefit from: SIX all-new
column6: one-hour webinar presentations provided by award-winning and bestselling science fiction and fantasy authors*
column7: all examining different aspects of writing novels in these genres. ¬†Each session will include an opportunity for live Q&A with the authors! A critique (with written feedback) of your query letter  from an agent with experience in the science fiction and fantasy genres.   A bonus 90-minute On Demand webinar covering how to write a query letter so you‚Äôre prepared when pitching your novel to agents. ¬†(A $79.99 value!) The ability to network with fellow science fiction and fantasy writers via discussion boards that will be open throughout the weekend. Share ideas
column8: and even your work if you choose. Unlimited OnDemand viewing! ¬†All conference  sessions will be made available for download in the week following the  live presentations. ¬†Even if you can‚Äôt attend every session live
column9: you  will be able to view each lecture on your own whenever you choose.  Learn Valuable Techniques to Hone Your Craft  	*Our craft-focused conference schedule is designed to provide the kind  of education that all science fiction and fantasy writers can use to  take their work to the next level. The following sessions are confirmed  for the event (Updated: ). Click on the ‚ÄúConference Schedule‚Äù tab for  the complete details on our lineup. All That Glitters: Building a Believable Magic System by Charlie N. Holmberg 	In this session
column10: we‚Äôll not only discuss the differing concepts and roles of magic systems
column11: but factor the implications of a magic system into the world surrounding it. 	 Lessons From the Pulps: How to Write Bestselling Science Fiction and Fantasy 	 by Philip Athans 	This 60-minute session will cover fiction as entertainment
column12: why the villain starts the story
column13: why the hero ends the story
column14: and more. 	  Merge Complex Science Seamlessly Into Your Fiction 	by Joe HartIn this 60-minute session
column15: bestselling author Joe Hart provides examples and tactics to meld complicated science concepts into gripping storylines that sell. 	  Using the Real in Your Science Fiction and Fantasy 	 	by Philippa (Pip) BallantineThe usual writing advice ‚Äúwrite  what you know‚Äù doesn‚Äôt seem to apply to speculative fiction
column16: but in fact  our world can certainly inspire and inform your writing. Learn how to  incorporate our real world into your science fiction and fantasy. Science Fiction Vs Science Fact: How Far Do You Go in the Science and When Do You Focus on Storytelling? by Tee Morris 	 	Science fiction is hard. Really hard. That may sound like an understatement
column17: but when writing in the genre
column18: you need to decide how far you want to go in showing your research into the pros and cons of generation ships
column20: and the physics behind a lightsaber. In this discussion hosted by award-winning science fiction author Tee Morris
column21: we discuss the fine line between knowledge and education against character development and storytelling. 	 Strangers in Strange Lands 	by 	Max Gladstone	 	World-building and character are different sides of the same  coin‚Äîespecially in science fiction and fantasy. No matter how intricate a  world you create
column22: your protagonist will reshape it with her will and  action; no matter how vivid a character you draw
column23: they‚Äôll be shaped and  limited by their context. Pitch Your Science Fiction or Fantasy Novel to a Literary Agent 	Join us for the live event and have a chance to get written feedback on  your query letter from a literary agent who works with science fiction  and fantasy authors. ¬†Participating agents include Kurestin Armada (P.S. Literary)
column25: and Lane Heymont (The Tobias Literary Agency).¬† Learn more or register at WritersOnlineWorkshops.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158433583987 "2017-03-15 13:00:32 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158433583987/meet-agent-eric-smith "The big question of the day‚Ä¶ *drum roll* how do you balance work with‚Ä¶ everything else?  I don‚Äôt? Hahah. I try my best
column2: but it does get hard sometimes. When  it comes to managing my own writing with the work of my clients as an  agent
column3: I always put their work first. I have a really hard time even  thinking about my own projects when I know I have their writing sitting  on my computer or my tablet or waiting to be sent out someplace.  Oddly enough
column4: it makes me work harder. If I really want to work on  some new personal project
column5: I absolutely have to be finished working on  everyone‚Äôs various projects and needs. Keeps me accountable. How would you describe your job to non-publishing professionals?  I pretty much have to do this every day when explaining my job to  my parents
column6: so
column7: I‚Äôm used to this. Literary agents work to discover  authors and get them published. We spend a lot of time polishing up  manuscripts with our clients
column8: researching the right editors for those  books
column9: and negotiating the best deals when they are presented.  But
column10: it goes a little further than that. We help manage careers
column11: dish out advice
column12: and guide through the publishing process. We watch over  contracts and terms
column13: make sure the author is getting what they are  promised. We handle rights for things
column14: selling books to foreign markets  and the like.  There‚Äôs a lot that goes into it
column15: making it way more than just ‚Äúselling books for people.‚Äù  I like to focus on the marketing end of things
column16: as that‚Äôs what I  did at my previous publishing job. I work with my authors on their  online presence
column17: when they want help with it. We talk about marketing  tactics they can tackles for their respective books.Using only one word
column18: describe yourself to your followers.  Eclectic.Continue reading at ANewLookOnBooks.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158392244300 "2017-03-14 13:00:49 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158392244300/how-to-nail-an-in-person-pitch-some-questions-you "I love taking in-person pitches at publishing conferences.It‚Äôs how I found Lindsey Smith (her book
column2: Eat Your Feelings
column3: comes out with St. Martin‚Äôs Press next year!)
column4: and I‚Äôve had the wonderful opportunity to talk with numerous writers  around the country. About their books
column5: about their platforms
column6: all kinds  of good stuff
column7: sharing advice as well as dishing out suggestions for  their projects.But without fail
column8: at every conference I attend
column9: there are certain  questions I ask that seem to trip writers up. And sometimes
column10: not having  answers to those questions sends up serious red flags.So I thought I‚Äôd do a little post
column11: to dish out some tips for those of  you pitching agents and editors in-person. Because while you may have  polished that pitch to perfection
column12: you‚Äôre going to need to answer these  kind of questions.1. What‚Äôs Your Book About?: Right away
column13: at every  conference I go to
column14: when I sit down with an author
column15: this is what I open  up with. Tell me about your book. What have you written? What‚Äôs it  about? Give me the details.This should be the quickest and easiest question to answer
column16: but sometimes it trips people up.Every writer comes prepared to talk about their book at these things.  It‚Äôs why you are there
column17: for the most part. But not every writer is able  to talk about their book in a quick
column20: maybe fifteen minutes here to sum up your entire  story.Don‚Äôt use this time to explain the entire intricate plot of the book.  This isn‚Äôt a book report. Treat it as though you‚Äôre reading the  back-jacket copy of a book to a friend in your local bookstore. You‚Äôre  shopping and you‚Äôre trying to sell them on this book. That‚Äôs what you  would show them.You can read the jacket copy of a book in a minute or two. You want  to have plenty of time for the agent to ask YOU questions and for you to  ask your own. Don‚Äôt spend it explaining every little thing. Save room.2. How Many Words?: Know the word count of your book. Agents and editors are going to ask this.And that being said
column21: before you even get ready to pitch
column22: know what  the typical word count is for your respective genre. If you show up  boasting an enormous
column23: unheard of word count for a book
column24: it might tell  the agent / editor that you‚Äôre not familiar with the genre.Writer‚Äôs Digest has a great post about typical book lengths here. There are exceptions to every rule
column25: of course. Just be savvy.Continue reading at EricSmithRocks.com" True link

column1: psliterary 158269452186 "2017-03-11 14:30:26 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158269452186/selling-your-childrens-book-how-to-write-and "psliterary: The agents of P.S. Literary Agency are teaming up for a Writer‚Äôs Digest Boot Camp! Children‚Äôs books‚Äîyoung adult
column2: middle grade
column3: and picture books‚Äîhave  taken over the publishing industry (in a good way). Readers of all ages  are devouring the books that used to only take up space in libraries
column4: children‚Äôs bookshelves
column5: or school classrooms. Now
column6: children‚Äôs books are  celebrated for their enchanting prose
column7: their relatable characters
column8: their  beautiful illustrations
column9: and their fantastic stories that transcend age  category. The growth of the children‚Äôs book sector has been  unprecedented this past decade‚Äîso how can you make your manuscript stand  out in these crowded categories and genres? In this Writer‚Äôs  Digest Boot Camp starting March 13
column10: the agents of P.S. Literary Agency  will show you how to make your submission stand out. How do you write a  children‚Äôs book with commercial appeal? How do you decide what category  and genre your book belongs in? How do you find agents and publishers to  submit your manuscript to? How can you attract both child and adult  readers (and buyers)? The agent instructors will answer these  questions‚Äîand more! They will also critique your work and answer any  questions you have about writing and selling books for children. As a  registrant
column11: you can choose to hear a tutorial on how to craft an amazing  picture book
column12: and then have your picture book critiqued‚Äîor you can  choose to hear a different tutorial on writing middle grade and young  adult fiction
column13: and then have the first five pages of your YA/MG  manuscript critiqued.  This program will show writers of Young Adult and Middle Grade the following: What the difference is between Middle Grade and Young Adult fiction How to create engaging characters that agents
column15: and readers will love Where (and where not) in the your story to start the manuscript  How to avoid the most common mistakes found in Young Adult and Middle Grade manuscripts
column16: such as talking down to your audience How to use common Middle Grade and Young Adult tropes  What the biggest genres are in Middle Grade and Young Adult fiction right now‚Äîand how to decide where your manuscript fits in What to highlight in your pitch to sell your book to agents and publishers What you can learn from your favorite Young Adult and Middle Grade novels This program will show writers of Picture Books the following: What the state of the market looks like for picture books How to learn from previous bestsellers How to come up with a great story that‚Äôs character- and plot-driven How to create a page-turning arc that will keep kids coming back Why rhythm
column18: is the key to success How to think visually and how to work with illustrators  How to avoid the ‚Äúdon'ts"" in writing for children How to inspire kids without writing heavy morals For more details or to register visit Writers Digest University. " False link

column1: psliterary 158109735894 "2017-03-07 14:30:39 GMT" http://psliterary.tumblr.com/post/158109735894/away-not-down-is-2017s-but-does-it-spark "Intent  on making 2017 your Best Year Ever? We can help with that
column2: thanks to  our 2017 Coach of the Month series. Here
column3: Rachel Hoffman‚Äîwho authored the just-released book Unf*ck Your Habitat: You‚Äôre Better Than Your Mess‚Äîshares her no-nonsense but actually realistic approach to cleaning up your clutter. Of  all the habits you can incorporate into your daily routine to make  cleaning up around the house easier
column4: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt put it down
column5: put it away‚Äù  seems like the most obvious. Because
column6: yeah
column7: if you put things away
column8: your  home stays cleaner. Couldn‚Äôt get more straightforward than that
column9: right?  Well
column10: obviously it‚Äôs not that simple
column11: or we‚Äôd all have immaculate homes  already.So
column12: how do you retrain yourself to put things back in their proper homes  the first time? First
column13: it‚Äôs worth taking a look at what you‚Äôre already  doing. When you come home from the store
column14: do you put everything in the  bags away right away
column15: or do you still have purchases in bags sitting on  the counter a day or a week later? When you kick off those shoes after a  long day
column16: do they end up back in the closet
column17: or do they just stay where  they landed? After using the scissors or can opener or nail file
column18: do  you just set them down on whatever surface is closest to you
column19: or do you  take the time to put them back where they belong? We end up putting  things down and not away over and over throughout the day
column20: and all of  those little things can add up to one big mess.Continue reading at Elle.comTeam UFYH‚Äôs Rachel Hoffmann is Coach of the Month over at Elle  Magazine!! Be sure to pick up the March issue and keep checking the  website for tips and articles all month long!¬† " True link
